g.text: Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
between reported results are sometimes complicated, but the overall deﬁnition describes HWs as time
spans of consecutive days with hotter conditions than usual [
]. To contribute to the uniﬁcation
e
ﬀ
orts of the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO), the indices deﬁned by the Expert Teamon
Sector-speciﬁc Climate Indices (ET-SCI) were used in this study. In general, past heat waves are a well
investigated phenomena, e.g., the Chicago HWfrom1995 [
] or the Paris HWfrom2003 [
For the assessment of future frequencies and intensities of HWs, climate change projections are useful
tools to derive potential future risks [
In our analysis, we rely on a multi-physics and multi-model ensemble of di
ﬀ
erent regional climate
models forced with two di
ﬀ
erent emission scenarios (RCP4.5 and RCP8.5.). No weighting of the
individual model results was used. To reduce the noise of the results, averages of 30-year time spans
were calculated and it was these results that were ﬁnally used for the statistical analysis [
The projected changes in air temperature for the three di
ﬀ
erent cities shown in Figure
are in
line with results from comparable studies for London [
], Luxembourg [
] and Rome [
For London, an increase in the long-termannual mean air temperature by 1.5
C for the RCP4.5 and
C for the RCP8.5 is projected. Past research demonstrated that there is a clear link between
increased mortality and increased air temperature and HWs [
] and heat-related diseases like
respiratory and cardiovascular illnesses [
]. In addition, there is a strong relationship between
increased air temperatures and ampliﬁed near surface ozone concentrations that reinforce the negative
health e
ﬀ
ects [
]. According to recent studies in England and Wales the mortality increases by
2.1% for each 1
C increase in air temperature above the 95th percentile of the average yearly
temperature [
]. With 1.6
C and 2.8
C the projected increase in air temperature is a bit more
pronounced for Luxembourg. The consequences for the regional fauna and ﬂora were analysed in
di
ﬀ
erent climate change impact studies in the past [
]. For Rome the highest anomalies of
up to 4.5
C were projected corresponding to results shown for the Mediterranean region [
The duration of the heat wave expressed as WSDI, shown in Figure
, can be used as a measure
for howlong the population is exposed to high levels of heat stress. Acontinuous increase in the WSDI
could be observed for all cities with the highest anomalies for Rome and RCP8.5, which is consistent
with the trends in the mean annual air temperature shown in Figure
. Long-term, continuous exposure
to high ambient air temperatures—targeted by this index—during the nights can decrease sleep quality
signiﬁcantly [
] especially for older people [
]. The WSDI was already applied for the past climate
worldwide based on the HadEX2 data set [
]. In Europe for the time span 1961–2010, positive trends
between 2.3 and 2.9 days per decade [
] could be observed. The impacts of projected changes in air
temperature based on that index were analysed e.g., for China [
], showing a statistically signiﬁcant
increase of 2.4 days per decade on average since 1961.
The index shown in Figure
comprises the absolute number of HWs per year (HW-N) and is
strongly related to the index describing the number of days (Figure
) that contribute to HWs per year
(HW-F). The absolute number of days that contribute to HWs inﬂuences the number and the duration
of the events but HW-F is not equal to HW-D multiplied with HW-N, because HW-D indicates the
duration of the longest event, not the average duration [
Based on the “in the meantime updated SRES emission scenarios” an increase in the globally
averaged (land only) number of HWs between 4 and 12 depending on the emission scenario was
simulated [
]. Although there is not much difference in the number of heat waves between the two
scenarios, the number of days’ contribution to heat waves each year with reference to the 30-year period
1971–2000 increases significantly following the projected general increase in air temperature. It is worth
noticing, that the arithmetic mean of the HW-Nanomalies for Rome in the RCP8.5 scenario for the far
future is lower (
4.0 HW) than that for London (
4.1 HW) and Luxembourg (
4.2 HW) and additionally,
the increase for the far future is less pronounced here than for the other indices. This could be explained
by the fact that the increased number of days that contribute to HWs prolonged the length of the HWs
substantially, so that fewbut very long HWs occur in all three cities every year at the end of this century.
This is reconfirmed by the results presented in Figure
. The HW-D index—describing the length of the
